page.title: 12Westbury Court Gardens
page.content:
Westbury Court Garden is unique, it is almost the only remaining Dutch water garden in the country. The present entrance is from the A48 road through the two lion topped pillars to the end of Court Gardens where, by a car park is the gate embellished by a pair of burogue urns from Ebworth Park and set up here in 1983.
The National Trust accepted the gardens in 1967 in a deplorable state and now in 1985 it has been restored as near to an engraving, recorded around 1705 by Johanes Kip. The road wall and west wall have wrought iron "clairvoyees" inserted so that the enclosure of the garden can been seen from many angles - most especialy from those residents who have rooms on the upper floor of the Home.
